newsitem.title: USA: Casino Data shares plunge after downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Casino Data shares plunge after downgrade.

text.p: A sharp decline by Casino Data Systems Corp stock on Monday was a matter of Wall Street looking fpr the "worst-case scenario" on the company's fiscal 1997 earnings estimates, an analyst said.

"The company made no announcements today," said Steve Bernard, an analyst at EVEREN Securities, "But analysts may have felt they may have been slighted. Part of the problem is that the company doesn't even know (how sales will be in 1997) yet."

Montgomery Securities and Rodman & Renshaw on Monday both downgraded Casino Data Systems. Montgomery analyst David McDonald said he did not expect the Las Vegas-based company to meet fourth-quarter earnings estimates, and he cut the 1997 estimate to $0.65 per share from $0.85.

Rodman analyst Daniel Devila left the 1997 estimate of $1.03 unchanged, but downgraded the stock to neutral from buy. Devila said he didn't have confidence in the company's management to help analysts make reliable estimates.
Casino Data's stock touched an all-time low of 8-1/4, closing the session down 4-1-8 at 8-1/2.
Company officials were unavailable for comment on the stock slide or the downgrades. A spokesman said late Monday afternoon a statement was being prepared.
Casino Data makes slot acccounting and player tracking equipment for the casino gaming industry.
